title.narrative: Building the Capacity of the Government of Angola in Countering Wildlife Trafficking in Cabinda Province

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the efforts of Ministry of Environment of Angola (MINAMB) to disrupt the supply-chain and counter wildlife trafficking in Angola, with a specific focus on Maiombe National Park and surrounding areas of Cabinda Province. This project is intended to help conserve CITES-listed and threatened species that are poached within Maiombe National Park, which may then enter illegal wildlife trade markets, including the IUCN Red List listed African grey parrot (Psittacus erithacus; Endangered), leopard (Panthera pardus; Vulnerable), white-bellied tree pangolin (Manis tricuspids; Vulnerable), and giant ground pangolin (Manis gigantean; Vulnerable). The central chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes troglodytes; Endangered), western lowland gorilla (Gorilla gorilla gorilla; Critically Endangered), and forest elephant (Loxodonta cyclotis; Vulnerable) share habitat and face similar risks and, as such, are expected to also benefit from this project. Specific activities will include: (1) strengthening the legislative framework for implementation of CITES and enforcement of wildlife crime law; 2) enhancing capacity through targeted trainings that develop in-country capacity and expertise on CITES implementation; 3) developing a permit system and enforcement database; 4) enhancing enforcement capacity through high-level intelligence training and mentoring; and 5) increasing the likelihood and success of enforcement actions through training for enforcement officers and rangers on safe handling, veterinary care and CITES-compliant disposition of confiscated wildlife.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
